for Object-Oriented Programming
Object-oriented programming (OOP) was introduced in the 1960s, when developers of the languages Simula 67 and BCPL began to design languages for computers that were not simply recompiled versions of assembler, but that created programs out of objects instead of  code   and  data   statements.   In   the  1970s   object-oriented programming was further explored and defined as a design style in Simula.   With  the  invention  of  Smalltalk, a language based on Simula that included most of the ideas originally developed by the creators of that language, it became clear that object-oriented programming was a distinct programming style.
Object-oriented programming provides a means of organizing programs and data into abstract data types, called objects. An object is an instance of a type, and can consist of any number of fields (also called variables, or attributes) that can store values of a specified type. A class describes an object type, including its fields and methods (also called functions, or operations).
In object-oriented programming, a single piece of code executes in a program, called a class. Objects are classes that are created from code that are instances. A class definition must be created before an object is created. An object may contain several properties (also known as attributes) such as a first name and last name, an email address, and a list of favorite movies. These properties compose an object's state. An object's state can change over time. An object's behavior is typically described by a set of methods, which are called during execution to complete the object's operations. Executing an object is called instantiation.
In object-oriented programming, functions may be written using object-oriented programming constructs or using the more traditional procedural programming constructs. Objects may be used to simplify the creation and use of common programming functions. Objects contain a set of state and behavior data (i.e., variables and functions) that is shared between multiple procedures or programs. Using object-oriented programming, large systems may be created by combining individual objects, similar to the way components are combined to create modules for hardware systems.
